choices.text: Most commonly followed technique is Inferior Pedicle Based Technique
Before this procedure, patients aged 35 years or above must undergo mammography
95% of patients have back and neck pain relief after the surgery
The lower age limit to do this procedure is 18 years

questions.text: In reduction mammoplasty technique, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the Answer:

  • The inferior pedicle technique is the most widely performed reduction mammoplasty procedure.
  • Variations include superior, medial, lateral, central, and doubly attached pedicle techniques (vertical and horizontal).
  • Before performing reduction mammoplasty, a baseline mammogram and clinical breast examination are recommended for all patients aged 35 years and above to rule out malignancy.
  • Most patients (approximately 97%) experience significant relief from back, shoulder, and neck pain following the surgery.
  • However, there is no fixed lower age limit of 18 years. Surgery may be considered earlier if breast hypertrophy is severe and causes physical or psychological distress.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Most commonly followed technique is Inferior Pedicle Based Technique (Option A): It preserves nipple-areolar complex viability and allows for substantial reduction.

Before this procedure, patients aged 35 years or above must undergo mammography (Option B): It is recommended for cancer screening prior to surgery.

95% of patients have back and neck pain relief after the surgery (Option C): Around 95-97% of patients report symptomatic improvement.

Key Takeaway:

Inferior pedicle technique is most common; screening mammography is advised for women ≥35 years; no strict lower age limit for the procedure.

choices.text: It's a logarithmic score of Creatinine, Bilirubin, and INR
Liver transplant is not advised if the score is <15
"Share 35" rule is used to allocate liver in a region
Status 1 - highest priority is given for HCC patients

questions.text: MELD Score is used in liver transplantation. Which of the following statements regarding the score is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the Answer:

  • The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is a logarithmic formula calculated using serum bilirubin, creatinine, and INR.
  • It is used to assess the severity of chronic liver disease and prioritize patients for liver transplantation.
  • Patients with MELD <15 are generally not advised for transplant because the mortality risk after transplantation exceeds the risk of waiting.
  • The "Share 35" rule ensures that patients with a MELD score ≥35 are given regional priority for liver allocation.
  • The highest priority (Status 1) is reserved for patients with acute liver failure (e.g., fulminant hepatic failure), not for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

It's a logarithmic score of Creatinine, Bilirubin, and INR (Option A): These parameters reflect liver and renal function, forming the basis of the MELD equation.

Liver transplant is not advised if the score is <15 (Option B): Patients with MELD <15 have better outcomes without immediate transplantation.

"Share 35" rule is used to allocate liver in a region (Option C): This rule prioritizes patients with a MELD score ≥35 for regional organ sharing.

Key Takeaway:

MELD score prioritizes liver allocation based on disease severity, not tumor status. Status 1 applies to acute liver failure, not HCC.

choices.text: The patients are recognized at birth itself
1st Branchial remnant is present behind back of ear
2nd Branchial remnant is least common type
3rd Branchial cleft is seen anterior to SCM in upper third

questions.text: Regarding branchial cysts and sinuses, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the Answer:

  • Branchial cysts and sinuses arise due to persistence of branchial cleft or pouch remnants.
  • Although present since birth, they are often not recognized until later in life, typically when they become infected or enlarge.
  • First branchial cleft remnants are usually located in front or behind the ear or in the upper neck near the mandible.
  • Second branchial cleft remnants are the most common type, presenting along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM), usually in its upper half to lower third.
  • Third branchial cleft remnants are uncommon and are found in the suprasternal or clavicular region, often containing cartilage and presenting as a firm swelling or abscess.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

The patients are recognized at birth itself (Option A): Although present at birth, branchial remnants are typically recognized later in life, not at birth.

2nd Branchial remnant is least common type (Option C): The second branchial cleft is the most common, not the least common.

3rd Branchial cleft is seen anterior to SCM in upper third (Option D): The third cleft is found low in the neck, near the suprasternal notch or clavicle, not along the SCM.

Key Takeaway:

First branchial remnants are found around the ear or upper neck, while second cleft cysts are most common and located along the anterior border of SCM.

choices.text: X-ray shows pneumoperitoneum in perforated appendicitis
Normal appendix is up to 8 mm thick on CT/USG and is non-compressible
MRI with gadolinium contrast is used in pregnant women
USG has 80% sensitivity

questions.text: Regarding investigations for acute appendicitis, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation of the Answer:

  • Ultrasonography (USG) abdomen is one of the primary diagnostic modalities used in acute appendicitis, especially in children and pregnant women due to the absence of radiation exposure.
  • It demonstrates an enlarged, immobile, non-compressible appendix with a thickened wall and periappendiceal echogenic changes.
  • The sensitivity of USG is about 80%, and the specificity is 90%.
  • Although CT is more accurate overall, MRI has the highest diagnostic accuracy among all imaging modalities, particularly in pregnant women.
  • MRI is typically reserved for use in pregnancy and performed without contrast agents, as gadolinium is contraindicated.
  • The sensitivity of MRI is 100%, the specificity 98%, the positive predictive value 98%, and the negative predictive value 100%.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

X-ray shows pneumoperitoneum in perforated appendicitis (Option A): Plain X-ray is not very useful in appendicitis - only 5% of cases show a fecolith. Pneumoperitoneum, if seen, usually indicates another perforated viscus such as peptic ulcer or diverticulitis, rather than appendicitis, even if perforated.

Normal appendix is up to 8 mm thick on CT/USG and is non-compressible (Option B): A normal appendix measures ≤6 mm and is compressible on USG. In acute appendicitis, the appendix is >7 mm in diameter, thick-walled, and shows mural enhancement ("target sign").

MRI with gadolinium contrast is used in pregnant women (Option C): MRI in pregnancy is done without contrast agents, since gadolinium crosses the placenta and may cause fetal harm. CECT can be done in the second trimester if MRI is unavailable.

Key Takeaway:

USG abdomen has 80% sensitivity and 90% specificity in diagnosing appendicitis.

MRI without contrast is the most accurate imaging technique, with 100% sensitivity and 98% specificity.

Plain X-rays are rarely diagnostic; pneumoperitoneum in appendicitis should prompt evaluation for other causes.

choices.text: This is a case of achalasia cardia
AP view X-ray of barium swallow is ideal
Endoscopy and manometry will confirm the diagnosis
Endoscopically done procedure may help this patient have a permanent solution

questions.text: A 70-year-old gentleman, Mr. Ramu, presents with complaints of food sticking in the throat, associated with cough and fever. He was admitted and evaluated for COVID-19 due to respiratory symptoms. Chest X-ray shows a lung abscess in the right lower lobe. The duty surgeon, suspecting an underlying cause, advises a barium swallow. Examination reveals a soft swelling in the neck. He asks his junior resident which of the following statements is true:
questions.solution:
Explanation of the Answer:

  • This is a classic case of Zenker's diverticulum, also known as a pharyngeal pouch or cricopharyngeal achalasia, which is the most common esophageal diverticulum found today.
  • It is typically seen in elderly men (7th decade) and occurs due to herniation of the mucosa through a weak area known as Kilian's dehiscence, located between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles of the inferior constrictor.
  • The most common symptom is dysphagia at the throat level, often accompanied by regurgitation of undigested food, gurgling in the neck, and aspiration, which can lead to lung abscess, as seen in this patient.
  • The investigation of choice (IOC) is a barium swallow with lateral view of the neck, which typically shows the posterior outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa.
  • Endoscopy is avoided initially due to the risk of perforation, but endoscopic stapling procedures (such as endoscopic cricopharyngeal myotomy) provide a definitive and permanent solution.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

This is a case of achalasia cardia (Option A): Achalasia cardia involves failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, causing dysphagia for both solids and liquids, and is unrelated to pharyngeal pouch formation.

AP view X-ray of barium swallow is ideal (Option B): The lateral view of the neck during barium swallow is ideal for demonstrating the diverticulum, as it clearly outlines the posterior pouch arising at the pharyngoesophageal junction.

Endoscopy and manometry will confirm the diagnosis (Option C): These are not recommended as initial diagnostic tools due to the risk of perforation. Barium swallow remains the preferred diagnostic modality.

Key Takeaway:

Zenker's diverticulum is the most common esophageal diverticulum, best diagnosed by lateral view barium swallow, and definitively treated by endoscopic procedures such as cricopharyngeal myotomy.

choices.text: Golden period for untwisting is <6 hours
Degree of twisting is a deciding factor for testis survival
Most common cause is Bell-Clapper deformity
Four absorbable sutures are used to fix both testes on bilateral exploration

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy, Mr. Somu, returned from a football game with severe pain in his right testis. Clinical evaluation and duplex scan confirm testicular torsion. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Testicular torsion is an acute urological emergency that results from twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to testicular ischemia.
  • The most common cause in adolescents is the Bell-Clapper deformity, where the tunica vaginalis abnormally attaches high on the spermatic cord, allowing free rotation of the testis.
  • Two critical factors determine the degree of testicular damage:
    • Duration of torsion, and
    • Degree of twisting.
  • Testicular survival is 100% if detorsion is done within 6 hours, but it drops to 20% after 24 hours. Hence, early diagnosis and intervention are crucial.
  • During surgery, a transverse scrotal incision is made, and both testes are explored. The affected testis is detorsed and fixed if viable.
  • Three non-absorbable sutures (not absorbable) are used to fix each testis to the scrotal raphe to prevent recurrence.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Golden period for untwisting is <6 hours (Option A): The best salvage rate is achieved when detorsion is performed within 6 hours of onset. Beyond this, irreversible ischemic necrosis begins.

Degree of twisting is a deciding factor for testis survival (Option B): The greater the torsion (e.g., >720°), the faster the onset of ischemic injury, which compromises testicular viability even if detorsed early.

Most common cause is Bell-Clapper deformity (Option C): This congenital deformity predisposes to torsion by allowing excessive mobility of the testis within the tunica vaginalis.

Four absorbable sutures are used to fix both testes on bilateral exploration (Option D): Fixation is performed with three non-absorbable sutures per testis to prevent retorsion. Absorbable sutures can dissolve, leading to recurrence.

Key Takeaway:

Bell-Clapper deformity is the commonest cause of testicular torsion. Testicular salvage depends on duration and degree of torsion. Detorsion within 6 hours offers the best outcome, and non-absorbable sutures are used for bilateral fixation.

choices.text: Thrombosis of axillary vein
Follows excessive exercises
Cervical rib may compress and result in this disease
If vein is compressed on elevation of arm on imaging - Venous bypass is done

questions.text: Regarding Paget-Schrotter disease which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paget-Schrötter disease (also called effort thrombosis) is a form of axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis seen in young individuals who perform repetitive or strenuous upper limb activity (e.g., athletes, manual laborers).
  • The condition occurs due to compression of the subclavian vein at the thoracic outlet, often worsened by excessive exercise or hypertrophied muscles, and can also be associated with a cervical rib or abnormal thoracic outlet anatomy.
  • In early stages, the arm becomes swollen and painful, and thrombolytic therapy can help restore venous patency.
  • If imaging shows compression on arm elevation, the treatment of choice is surgical decompression-usually removal of the first rib or cervical rib, not venous bypass.
  • Hence, Option D is false because bypass is not indicated; decompression is the preferred management once thrombosis resolves.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Thrombosis of axillary vein (Option A): Paget-Schrötter disease involves thrombosis of the axillary-subclavian vein, typically on the dominant side, due to repetitive shoulder motion.

Follows excessive exercises (Option B):It frequently follows strenuous activity or repetitive arm motion, which causes intimal damage and venous stasis, precipitating thrombosis.

Cervical rib may compress and result in this disease (Option C): A cervical rib or other anatomical anomalies of the thoracic outlet may compress the subclavian vein, predisposing to thrombosis.

Key Takeaway:

Paget-Schrötter disease is an effort-induced axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis.
Early thrombolysis and surgical decompression (rib resection) are the mainstays of treatment, not venous bypass.

choices.text: Xenograft valves have minimal turbulence
Mechanical valves have thrombogenic property
Most common complication is thrombus formation for both biological and mechanical valves
Structural valve failure is common with mechanical valves

questions.text: False statement regarding prosthetic heart valves is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Prosthetic valves are broadly classified into mechanical and biological (tissue) Each type has distinct complications and performance profiles.
  • Structural valve failure refers to degeneration or disruption of the valve components that affects function.
  • This is common with biological (xenograft) valves, which degenerate over time, especially in younger patients. Mechanical valves, on the other hand, are highly durable and structural valve failure is almost never seen in them.
  • Hence, Option D is false because structural failure is not a feature of mechanical valves.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Xenograft valves have minimal turbulence (Option A): Biological valves (xenografts or homografts) closely mimic native valve anatomy, producing minimal turbulence and low shear stress on blood flow.

Mechanical valves have thrombogenic property (Option B): Mechanical valves have a high risk of thrombosis, necessitating lifelong anticoagulation with warfarin to prevent thromboembolic complications.

Most common complication is thrombus formation for both biological and mechanical valves (Option C): Thrombosis and thromboembolism are the most common complications in prosthetic valves, particularly mechanical valves, but can also occur in biological ones, though less frequently.

Key Takeaway:

Structural valve failure occurs most commonly in biological valves, not mechanical ones.
Thrombosis is the most frequent complication overall, and lifelong anticoagulation is mandatory for mechanical valves.

choices.text: Donor site gets more brisk punctate spots if the graft is thicker
Thicker grafts are less durable once healed
Thicker graft donor area is difficult to heal
Grafts are hairless and do not sweat

questions.text: False statement regarding split-thickness partial grafts is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A split-thickness skin graft (STSG) includes the epidermis and a variable portion of dermis, leaving enough dermis at the donor site to allow epithelial regeneration.
  • Thicker grafts (with more dermis) are more durable and undergo less secondary contracture than thinner grafts. Therefore, the statement that "thicker grafts are less durable once healed" is false.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Donor site gets more brisk punctate spots if the graft is thicker (Option A): With thicker knife settings, fewer but brisker bleeding points are seen at the donor site, as more dermis is removed.

Thicker graft donor area is difficult to heal (Option C): Thicker graft donor sites take longer to heal because less dermis remains, which delays epithelial regeneration.

Grafts are hairless and do not sweat (Option D): Hair follicles and sweat glands are located deep in the dermis and are not transferred in split-thickness grafts; hence, grafted skin remains hairless and anhidrotic.

Key Takeaway:

Thicker split-thickness grafts are more durable and have less contracture, while thinner grafts heal faster but are less resistant to trauma.

choices.text: Tensile strength of the scar reaches 100% of the normal skin in 2 years
Atrophic scar needs excision and re-suturing
Hypertrophic scar is due to incision along lines of skin tension
In keloids there is excess deposition of Type II collagen

questions.text: True statement regarding scars is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atrophic scars are thin, depressed scars where both epidermis and dermis are attenuated, making them easily traumatized. These scars occur due to tissue loss or poor wound edge approximation.
  • The recommended management is surgical excision and re-suturing, which restores skin integrity and improves cosmetic outcome.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Tensile strength of the scar reaches 100% of the normal skin in 2 years (Option A): Even after complete healing, the tensile strength never exceeds 60-80% of normal skin, regardless of treatment. This is because the collagen fibers in scars are less organized than in normal dermis.

Hypertrophic scar is due to incision along lines of skin tension (Option C): Hypertrophic scars occur due to unfavourable incision placement-that is, across the lines of skin tension, not along them. They remain confined to the original wound margins and are common after high-tension closures.

In keloids there is excess deposition of Type II collagen (Option D): Keloids result from excess deposition of Type III collagen (not Type II, which is found in cartilage). They extend beyond the original wound edges, are inherited, and are most common over the xiphisternum and shoulder tip.

Key Takeaway:

Atrophic scars are managed by surgical excision and re-suturing, while hypertrophic scars remain within wound margins, and keloids extend beyond, showing excess Type III collagen.

choices.text: Left RLN hooks around the Arch of aorta and Right under Right Subclavian Artery
The nerve enters the larynx at the Cricothyroid joint at the level of Berry's ligament and this is the most common site of injury of RLN
The nerve can be identified as a content of Beahr's triangle
The nerve can be identified after mobilising the thyroid gland lying at the most posterolateral portion of the gland known as the Tubercle of Zuckerkandl

questions.text: Regarding the Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) - which of the following statements is wrong?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) is crucial in thyroid and parathyroid surgery because of its close relation to the gland and its high risk of injury.
  • The RLN is not a content but a boundary of Beahr's triangle (also known as the tracheoesophageal or surgical triangle).
  • The boundaries of this triangle are:
    • Medially: Trachea
    • Laterally: Common carotid artery
    • Superiorly: Inferior thyroid artery
    • Posteriorly: RLN forms the posteromedial boundary, not the content.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Left RLN hooks around the Arch of aorta and Right under Right Subclavian Artery (Option A): The left RLN loops around the arch of the aorta, making it longer and more medial, while the right RLN loops around the right subclavian artery, making it shorter and more oblique. About 2% of right RLNs are non-recurrent, entering the larynx directly from above.

The nerve enters the larynx at the Cricothyroid joint at the level of Berry's ligament and this is the most common site of injury of RLN (Option B): The RLN ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove and enters the larynx posterior to the cricothyroid joint near Berry's ligament, where it is most vulnerable to injury during thyroidectomy due to its close fixation to the gland.

The nerve can be identified after mobilising the thyroid gland lying at the most posterolateral portion of the gland known as the Tubercle of Zuckerkandl (Option D): The Tubercle of Zuckerkandl serves as an important landmark for identification of the RLN, as the nerve usually lies just medial or deep to it.

Key Takeaway:

The RLN forms the boundary, not the content, of Beahr's triangle and is most commonly injured near Berry's ligament during thyroid surgery.

choices.text: Dry gangrene is due to atheromatous occlusion.
In dry gangrene when proximal blood supply is adequate, the line of demarcation develops in a few days.
In dry gangrene if bone is also involved, the separation happens faster than soft tissues alone.
If bone is also involved, the stump is conical.

questions.text: Dry gangrene of foot - which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dry gangrene results from gradual atheromatous occlusion of arteries leading to ischemic necrosis without infection.
  • The tissues become dry, black, and shriveled due to slow mummification.
  • When proximal blood flow is adequate, an early line of demarcation develops between viable and dead tissue due to inflammatory reaction.
  • However, when proximal circulation is poor, this demarcation is delayed or may not occur at all - resulting in skip lesions and infection.
  • If bone is involved, separation is slower, not faster, because bone resorption and sequestration take more time compared to soft tissue sloughing.
  • The black color is produced by iron sulphide, formed from the reaction between hydrogen sulphide and haemoglobin breakdown products.
  • Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Dry gangrene is due to atheromatous occlusion (Option A): The commonest cause of dry gangrene is atherosclerotic occlusion of peripheral arteries, especially in the elderly. It is most often seen in the toes and foot.

In dry gangrene when proximal blood supply is adequate, the line of demarcation develops in a few days (Option B): Adequate proximal perfusion promotes inflammatory hyperemia at the junction of viable and necrotic tissue, producing a clear line of demarcation within a few days.

If bone is also involved, the stump is conical (Option D): As the bone retains its blood supply longer than soft tissue, the soft tissue sloughs off first, leaving the bone projecting-resulting in a conical stump typical of dry gangrene with bony involvement.

Key Takeaway:

In dry gangrene, bone involvement delays separation because osseous necrosis progresses slowly, whereas soft tissue necrosis separates earlier. A conical stump indicates ischemic necrosis extending to bone.

choices.text: Blood urea
Hemoglobin
Blood pressure
Endoscopy findings

questions.text: Blatchford score used for screening patients at risk of serious upper gastrointestinal bleeding includes all the following variables except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Blatchford score is a screening and risk stratification tool used in patients presenting with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) to identify those at risk of needing therapeutic intervention such as transfusion, endoscopy, or surgery.
  • It is calculated based on clinical and laboratory parameters available before endoscopy, hence serving as a pre-endoscopic score.
  • The parameters include:
  • Blood urea
    • Hemoglobin
    • Systolic blood pressure (BP)
    • Pulse rate (PR)
    • Clinical markers such as melena, syncope, hepatic disease, or cardiac failure
  • A score > 0 predicts a high likelihood of requiring medical or surgical intervention with a sensitivity of around 99%.
  • Endoscopy findings are not included in the Blatchford score because it is applied before endoscopic evaluation to decide which patients require urgent endoscopy and which can be managed conservatively.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Blood urea (Option A): Blood urea level is included because elevated urea reflects nitrogen absorption from degraded blood in the gut, indicating the presence and severity of GI bleeding.

Hemoglobin (Option B): Hemoglobin level is included to assess degree of anemia and blood loss severity. Lower levels correlate with higher risk and need for transfusion.

Blood pressure (Option C): Hypotension indicates hemodynamic compromise and predicts a need for urgent intervention. It is a key parameter in both Blatchford and Rockall scores.

Key Takeaway:

The Blatchford score is a screening tool used before endoscopy to identify patients at high risk for severe UGIB who may require urgent intervention.Endoscopy findings are not part of the scoring system.

choices.text: Inlay
Onlay
Sublay
Intraperitoneal Onlay

questions.text: Identify the type of mesh repair shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Sublay (Retromuscular or Rives-Stoppa) repair involves placement of the mesh between the posterior rectus sheath and the rectus muscle, or in the preperitoneal space.
  • This technique provides excellent reinforcement of the abdominal wall with minimal tension, reduced recurrence rate, and low risk of mesh infection, as the prosthesis is well protected from the subcutaneous tissue and skin.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Inlay (Option A): Here, the mesh is sutured edge-to-edge between fascial margins, leading to tension, poor reinforcement, and high recurrence rates.

Onlay (Option B): In this technique, the mesh is placed superficial to the anterior rectus sheath, which increases the risk of infection and seroma formation due to its proximity to subcutaneous tissues.

Intraperitoneal Onlay (Option D): This refers to IPOM, a laparoscopic technique where a dual-layer mesh (one side anti-adhesive, the other polypropylene) is fixed to the inner abdominal wall. It is not part of open hernia mesh placement planes.

Key Takeaway:

The Sublay (Retromuscular) method offers the best long-term outcomes among open mesh techniques-low recurrence, strong support, and minimal infection risk.

choices.text: Pericardial fluid
Retroperitoneal hemorrhage
Renal hematoma
Pneumothorax

questions.text: Following a blunt trauma injury, a FAST scan was performed. Which of the following sites cannot be evaluated by FAST?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is a rapid bedside ultrasound used to identify free fluid in the peritoneal, pericardial, and pleural cavities following trauma.
  • It evaluates for hemoperitoneum and hemopericardium, which are immediate life-threatening conditions in trauma settings.
  • The four standard FAST windows are:
    • Right upper quadrant (Morison's pouch) - detects hepatorenal fluid.
    • Left upper quadrant (splenorenal recess) - detects perisplenic fluid.
    • Pelvic (pouch of Douglas) - detects fluid in rectouterine or rectovesical space.
    • Subxiphoid (pericardial view) - detects pericardial effusion.
  • However, retroperitoneal hemorrhage is not visualized on FAST because the retroperitoneal space lies behind the peritoneum, making ultrasound detection of bleeding in this compartment extremely unreliable.
  • Extended FAST (E-FAST) may include pleural views for detection of pneumothorax or hemothorax, but even E-FAST cannot assess retroperitoneal or bowel injuries.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Pericardial fluid (Option A): FAST can effectively detect pericardial effusion or tamponade via the subxiphoid or parasternal window.

Renal hematoma (Option C): FAST can detect perinephric or subcapsular collections, though small hematomas may still be missed.

Pneumothorax (Option D): The E-FAST (Extended FAST) includes evaluation for pneumothorax using the absence of lung sliding sign or 'barcode' sign on M-mode ultrasonography.

Key Takeaway:

FAST is an excellent screening tool for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid, but not for retroperitoneal or hollow viscus injuries.Retroperitoneal hemorrhage requires CT scan with contrast for accurate detection.

choices.text: Tear of tunica vaginalis
Rupture of Buck's fascia leads to bleeding limited only to the penis (intra-penile hematoma)
Immediate surgical exploration and repair
Urethral injury is always associated

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with sudden detumescence, swelling, and pain in the penis following a loud 'pop' sound during sexual intercourse. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Penile fracture refers to a traumatic rupture of the tunica albuginea of one or both corpora cavernosa, most commonly occurring during sexual intercourse, especially when the female partner is on top.
  • Mechanism: When the erect penis slips out of the vagina and forcefully strikes the pubic symphysis or perineum, the tunica albuginea tears, resulting in sudden pain, detumescence, and swelling.
  • Clinical features:
    • Audible 'pop' sound at the time of injury
    • Immediate detumescence
    • Rapid penile swelling and pain
    • 'Eggplant deformity' - swollen, ecchymotic, and deviated penis
    • If Buck's fascia is disrupted, extravasation spreads into the perineum and scrotum, forming a 'butterfly-shaped hematoma.'
  • Treatment:
    • Immediate surgical exploration and repair is the gold standard.
    • Delay in surgery can lead to fibrosis, penile curvature, erectile dysfunction, and painful erection.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Tear of tunica vaginalis (Option A): The tunica vaginalis covers the testis, not the penis. In penile fracture, the structure torn is the tunica albuginea of the corpora cavernosa.

Rupture of Buck's fascia leads to bleeding limited only to the penis (Option B): If Buck's fascia remains intact, the hematoma is confined to the shaft of the penis. If Buck's fascia ruptures, bleeding spreads into the perineum and scrotum, forming a butterfly hematoma.

Urethral injury is always associated (Option D): Urethral injury is not always associated but occurs in about 10-20% of cases, especially if there is blood at the meatus or urinary retention.

Key Takeaway:

Penile fracture is caused by rupture of the tunica albuginea of the corpora cavernosa during erection.

Immediate surgical repair is the treatment of choice to prevent complications like fibrosis and erectile dysfunction.

choices.text: It is not associated with ascites
Most common in patients with cirrhotic liver
One symptom seen is fever
Diagnosed by paracentesis

questions.text: False statement regarding Primary Bacterial Peritonitis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spontaneous (Primary) Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP) is an acute bacterial infection of ascitic fluid without any evident intra-abdominal source of infection. It most commonly occurs in patients with cirrhosis and ascites due to portal hypertension.
  • Pathophysiology: Translocation of gut bacteria through an impaired intestinal mucosal barrier into mesenteric lymph nodes and ascitic fluid results in infection, even in the absence of a perforated viscus or secondary cause.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Fever is the most frequent symptom.
    • Abdominal tenderness, guarding, and rigidity may be present but are often less pronounced than in secondary peritonitis.
    • Nausea, vomiting, and worsening encephalopathy may occur.
    • GI bleeding and hemodynamic instability may complicate the presentation.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Investigations: Paracentesis is the investigation of choice (IOC) and must be done even with a low index of suspicion.
    • Diagnostic criteria: Neutrophil count ≥250/mm³ in the ascitic fluid.
    • Culture results:
      • Positive in only 40% of cases, most commonly showing coli, Streptococci, or Enterococci.
      • Negative in up to 60% of cases, despite clinical findings suggestive of infection.
  • Treatment:
    • Empirical therapy: Third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., cefotaxime, ceftriaxone).
    • Alternatives: Amoxicillin-clavulanate or Ciprofloxacin.
    • Early treatment has reduced mortality from over 90% to about 20%.
  • Complications:
    • Septic shock
    • GI bleeding
    • Hypoalbuminemia
    • Worsening hepatic encephalopathy

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Most common in patients with cirrhotic liver (Option B): SBP is most commonly associated with cirrhosis and ascites, particularly in advanced liver disease.

One symptom seen is fever (Option C): Fever is the most consistent presenting symptom.

Diagnosed by paracentesis (Option D): This is true - diagnostic paracentesis is the investigation of choice for confirmation and management planning.

Key Takeaway:

Primary bacterial peritonitis occurs only in the presence of ascitic fluid-it cannot develop without ascites.

Early diagnosis and prompt antibiotic therapy drastically reduce mortality.

questions.text: How long does PDS (Polydioxanone) take to get absorbed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Polydioxanone (PDS) is a synthetic monofilament absorbable suture
  • It is absorbed by hydrolysis, a process in which water molecules break the polymer chains of the suture, leading to gradual loss of tensile strength and complete absorption over several months.
  • Key Characteristics:
    • Structure: Monofilament, resulting in less tissue drag and reduced infection risk.
    • Absorption mechanism:
    • Absorption time: Complete absorption occurs within 90-180 days.
    • Tensile strength: Retains approximately 60-70% at 2 weeks and 40-50% at 4 weeks.
    • Tissue reaction: Minimal inflammatory response.
  • Uses:
    • Fascial closure
    • Gastrointestinal anastomoses
    • Urologic and pediatric surgeries
    • Delayed-healing tissues where prolonged support is required

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

270-360 days (Option A): This absorption duration corresponds to longer-lasting materials like some slow-degrading variants or non-absorbable sutures, not PDS.

60-90 days (Option C): Sutures like Polyglycolic acid (Dexon) or Polyglactin 910 (Vicryl) get absorbed within this time frame, not PDS.

10-15 days (Option D): This corresponds to catgut or rapidly absorbable sutures, which lose tensile strength quickly.

Key Takeaway:

PDS is a monofilament absorbable suture absorbed by hydrolysis within 90-180 days, ideal for tissues needing long-term tensile support with minimal tissue reaction.

questions.text: A 56-year-old gentleman underwent laparoscopic left hemicolectomy for a diagnosed left colonic carcinoma. Histopathology revealed the tumor to be invading the submucosa and muscularis propria. Among the 16 regional lymph nodes harvested, 2 were positive for malignant deposits. According to the AJCC 8th edition, what is the appropriate stage for this tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The AJCC 8th Edition Staging System for colorectal carcinoma uses the TNM classification, where staging is based on:

  • T (Tumor depth of invasion)
  • N (Regional lymph node involvement)
  • M (Distant metastasis)

T Stage (Tumor):

  • T1: Tumor invades submucosa
  • T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria
  • T3: Tumor invades subserosa or pericolic fat, but not through the serosa
  • T4: Tumor perforates the visceral peritoneum or directly invades adjacent organs

In this case, invasion into submucosa and muscularis propria corresponds to T2.

N Stage (Nodes):

  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis
  • N1: Metastasis in 1-3 regional lymph nodes
  • N2: Metastasis in 4 or more regional lymph nodes

Here, 2 out of 16 nodes are positive, corresponding to N1.

M Stage (Metastasis):

  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis present

There is no evidence of distant metastasis, hence M0.

Therefore, the final staging is T2, N1, M0.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

T1, N1, M0 (Option A): T1 represents invasion into submucosa only, but in this case, the tumor has invaded muscularis propria as well.

T1, N0, M0 (Option C): No nodal involvement is seen in N0, but this case has 2 positive lymph nodes.

T2, N1, M1 (Option D): M1 indicates distant metastasis, which is not present in this case.

Key Takeaway:

In colon carcinoma, the depth of invasion determines T stage, lymph node status determines N stage, and distant spread determines M stage.

For this patient: T2 (muscularis propria) + N1 (1-3 nodes) + M0 (no metastasis) = Stage IIIA (T2N1M0) as per AJCC 8th edition.

questions.text: Refeeding syndrome seen after enteral or parenteral nutrition is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Refeeding Syndrome is a potentially life-threatening metabolic complication that occurs in severely malnourished patients who are started on enteral or parenteral nutrition-most commonly with total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
  • Pathophysiology: When carbohydrates are reintroduced after starvation, insulin secretion increases, driving phosphate, magnesium, and potassium into cells for glycolysis and energy production. This leads to severe electrolyte depletion in the serum.

Characteristic Laboratory Abnormalities:

  • Hypophosphatemia - hallmark finding
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypocalcemia may also be seen in some cases due to shifts related to phosphate metabolism
  • No significant hyponatremia - sodium levels are generally unaffected

Clinical Consequences:

  • Cardiac arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death (due to low phosphate and magnesium)
  • Respiratory failure (due to diaphragmatic weakness)
  • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Neurologic symptoms (confusion, seizures)

Prevention:

  • Identify high-risk patients (e.g., anorexia nervosa, chronic alcoholism, prolonged fasting, post-surgical malnutrition).
  • Reintroduce calories gradually.
  • Supplement phosphate, potassium, and magnesium before and during refeeding.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Hypophosphatemia (Option A): The most characteristic finding in refeeding syndrome due to rapid cellular uptake of phosphate for ATP production.

Hypocalcemia (Option B): Secondary to hypophosphatemia and intracellular shifts during refeeding.

Hypomagnesemia (Option C): Magnesium is driven into cells, contributing to cardiac instability and neuromuscular irritability.

Key Takeaway:

Refeeding syndrome is caused by metabolic shifts after nutritional replenishment in malnourished individuals and is characterized by hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia-not hyponatremia.
